node.title: Three ‘beloved’ snow leopards died of Covid complications at Nebraska zoo.
node.alt: A snow leopard at a zoo in San Diego, Calif.
node.description: The mountain cats had tested positive for the virus about a month ago.
node.content: ["Three snow leopards died of complications related to Covid-19 at a zoo in Lincoln, Neb., despite efforts by staff to restore them to health after they tested positive for the virus about a month ago, zoo announcements said.", "The Lincoln Children\u2019s Zoo lamented the deaths of Ranney, Everest and Makalu in a Facebook post on its official page Friday evening, saying the mountain cats \u201cwere beloved by our entire community inside and outside of the zoo.\u201d", "\u201cThis loss is truly heartbreaking, and we are all grieving together,\u201d the statement said.", "The snow leopards were not the only animals to have contracted the virus at the facility. The Lincoln Children\u2019s Zoo had published a statement on Oct. 13 disclosing that the snow leopards and Sumatran tigers had \u201ctested positive for the virus that causes Covid-19.\u201d", "The zoo had collected nasal swab and fecal samples after animal keepers had \u201cobserved symptoms consistent with the virus in felids,\u201d which can include respiratory illness. The zoo said it had been treating the snow leopards and tigers \u201cwith steroids and antibiotics to prevent secondary infection,\u201d but its statement did not say whether its animals had been vaccinated.", "This summer, zoo animals started receiving an experimental Covid vaccine made by Zoetis, a veterinary pharmaceutical company in New Jersey.", "The Lincoln zoo\u2019s tigers appeared to be pulling through, according to the latest statement. \u201cSumatran tigers, Axl and Kumar, have made a seemingly full recovery from the illness,\u201d the zoo said.", "Cases of Covid infections among zoo animals have surfaced throughout the U.S., including the first two spotted hyenas in the world found to have the virus, among other animals infected at the Denver Zoo. Other recently reported cases have included tigers in Omaha, Neb.; African lions, snow leopards, jaguars and a tiger in St. Louis and lions in Honolulu.", "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have said that the risk of animals spreading Covid-19 to people is considered low, but people can also spread the virus to them, and cases among pets and animals in zoos have been documented around the world.", "The Lincoln Children\u2019s Zoo, conceived as a family destination where children could come close to animals, houses over 400 animals, including more than 40 endangered species, according to its website. Zoo officials could not be immediately reached on Saturday, but the organization\u2019s statement said it has been following guidelines from the C.D.C. and the American Association of Zoo Veterinarians to protect its animals, the staff and the community."]
